Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrated Modeling of Sustainability and Reliability for Interdependent Infrastructure Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award is to provide an approach for assessing the economic, environmental, and social sustainability and reliability of interdependent power and water systems. This is intended to better support proactive management of public and private infrastructure, particularly in areas susceptible to natural hazards such as hurricanes and earthquakes. The research develops indicators for measuring trends in the sustainability of power and water systems, providing a basis for changing the management and funding of these systems to improve their sustainability. The project also provides new computational frameworks for modeling interdependent power and water systems. The impacts of natural hazards such as hurricanes and earthquakes will be combined with the effects of aging to develop a more holistic reliability modeling approach for infrastructure systems. The reliability and sustainability models are brought into the infrastructure management process to help support meaningful change in power and water systems in hazard-prone areas.

If successful, this work will contribute to the development of improved methods for assessing and managing aging infrastructure systems in the US. These improved methods would allow limited public and private funds to be used more efficiently to improve infrastructure systems before they fail rather than relying on a reactive approach of repairing failures after they occur. This project will also develop a series of on-line and classroom teaching materials for middle school, high school, college, graduate school, and professional education. These materials will help to further establish a pipeline of students who are interested and educated in infrastructure engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this grant focused on understanding and modeling electric power and water systems and how they perform during disasters and under normal conditions as they age. A number of significant advances were made in this project, some of which have had a an impact in practice, and others of which have advanced knowledge in the field of infrastructure engineering.

 One set of research advances was in the area of risk analysis for power systems in areas prone to hurricanes. Work on this project contributed to the development of hurricane power outage forecasting models. These models predict power outages before a hurricane makes landfall. This allows utility companies to be better prepared to restore power after the hurricanes. It also allows other types of utilities, particularly water utilities, to be better prepared to mitigate the impacts of power outages on the performance of their systems. This work has been implemented in practice by electric power utilities and the federal government to help guide hurricane response planning. The research team also extended this work to examine how risk to power systems would change in the future if the hurricane hazard environment changed due to climate non-stationarity. This work showed that areas of the country that in the past have had limited power outages due to hurricanes are the places most likely to see large increases in power outage risk from hurricanes. This suggests that a broader conversation about power outage risk is needed, particularly in selected areas with limited historical experience with hurricanes.  

 Another set of research advances was in the area of drinking water systems. The research team developed new methods for modeling pipe breaks in drinking water systems. These approaches are beginning to find application in industry as a way to help utilities plan pipe inspection and maintenance. Building from this, the team also developed new approaches to optimize inspection path for pipe inspection in water systems. This helps utilities better utilize their limited inspection budgets to target the highest risk pipes. The research team also developed new approaches for quantifying water system sustainability. This approach builds from existing approaches in the research literature but links different measures of sustainability together in a more rigorous, justifiable way. Finally, in the area of water systems, the team has conducted an assessment of existing industry standards for assessing risk in drinking water systems. In this work, we discussed theoretical and practical shortcoming of existing approaches and suggested changes to the approaches to improve them.

Finally, we have also conducted research on how to better understand and model power and water systems as interdependent infrastructure systems. This is particularly important because water systems are highly dependent on power systems for daily operations, and in the long run, electric power generation is dependent on water for cooling. We developed a new model for interdependent power and water systems based on methods from ecological modeling. We also used network theory models to better understand the properties of infrastructure networks that make them more of less robust in the face of natural hazards.

 Overall, the work on this grant has helped to advance our understanding of and ability to model power and water systems. This work has helped to increase the robustness of these systems to natural hazards.
